plastic bottle.dispose: Empty, rinse thoroughly, flatten to save space, and place PET bottles in your mixed recycling stream. Caps can usually stay on—verify with local guidance.
reduce: Carry a durable stainless-steel or glass reusable bottle to avoid impulse purchases.
Refill from public hydration stations or office water dispensers whenever possible.
Choose family-sized containers and decant into smaller reusable bottles at home.
Support brands that operate circular packaging or bottle-deposit programs.
Keep a spare reusable bottle in your bag or car to curb single-use cravings.
reuse: Cut and turn bottles into propagation stations for herbs and houseplants.
Create DIY watering globes for potted plants while traveling.
Use cleaned bottles as lightweight storage for dry goods on camping trips.
Transform into bird feeders by adding dowels and seed ports.
Craft LED lanterns or fairy-light diffusers for outdoor gatherings.
recycle_ideas: Shred and weave strips into colorful baskets or desk organizers.
Heat-form flattened bottles into durable plant labels.
Create modular wall art by painting and linking bottle bases.
Build vertical garden towers by stacking bottle planters.
Use bottle caps for mosaic projects or as counters for educational games.
plastic bottle.environmental_impact: PET plastic production relies on fossil fuels, emits greenhouse gases, and can take centuries to break down. Mismanaged bottles fragment into microplastics that harm marine life and enter food chains.
plastic bottle.local_rules: Most municipalities accept PET #1 bottles in curbside recycling. Keep them empty, lightly crushed, and free of liquids. Avoid mixing with PVC or PLA plastics, and follow deposit-return schemes where available.

glass bottle.dispose: Remove lids, give the bottle a quick rinse, and place it in a color-sorted glass bank or mixed recycling bin if your program allows commingled glass.
reduce: Favor beverages sold in refillable or returnable glass containers.
Purchase concentrates or syrups that dilute into many servings per bottle.
Support zero-waste shops offering bulk items in deposit jars.
Invest in countertop soda or water carbonators to skip bottled drinks.
Share large-format bottles at gatherings instead of multiple single-serve portions.
reuse: Convert bottles into table lamps or pendant lights with DIY kits.
Use as elegant storage for homemade oils, dressings, or infused spirits.
Label and repurpose as pantry jars for grains, beans, or dried fruit.
Create outdoor tiki torches by filling with citronella oil and wicks.
Turn stout bottles into rolling pins or pastry weights.
recycle_ideas: Tumble glass shards to create sea-glass style mosaics.
Slice bottles into rings for wind chimes or jewelry.
Sand down edges to craft drinking glasses or candle holders.
Use crushed glass as reflective mulch in succulent planters.
Embed glass chips in concrete stepping stones for garden art.
glass bottle.environmental_impact: Glass is infinitely recyclable without quality loss, but producing virgin glass is energy-intensive. Recycling significantly decreases energy use and raw material extraction.
glass bottle.local_rules: Deposit schemes may refund a small fee per bottle. Separate by color if your facility requires it, and avoid mixing ceramics or Pyrex, which melt at different temperatures.

metal can.dispose: Rinse the can, remove sharp lids, and place it in metal recycling. Crushing is optional but helps save bin space.
reduce: Cook from fresh or frozen ingredients to minimize reliance on canned goods.
Buy bulk-sized cans only when you can finish contents before spoilage.
Choose beverages in refillable growlers or kegs instead of single-use cans.
Plan meals to avoid multiple small cans of similar ingredients.
Support brands packaging in lightweight, recycled-content aluminum.
reuse: Turn cans into rustic utensil caddies with twine and labels.
Punch patterned holes to create candle lanterns or luminaries.
Use as planters for herbs, ensuring drainage holes at the base.
Flatten and cut into decorative garden markers.
Upcycle large cans into countertop compost crocks with charcoal filters.
recycle_ideas: Strip paint and craft metal tiles for wall art or backsplashes.
Make percussion instruments for music education workshops.
Cut and emboss thin sheets into holiday ornaments.
Fashion can tabs into bracelets or bag embellishments.
Use thick cans to create rocket-stove components for outdoor cooking.
metal can.environmental_impact: Aluminum and steel are highly recyclable, and reprocessing them saves up to 95% of the energy compared to mining new ore. Landfilled metal slowly oxidizes and wastes valuable resources.
metal can.local_rules: Most curbside programs accept steel and aluminum cans together. Keep them empty, avoid mixing with aerosol cans unless fully depressurized, and leave paper labels on—they burn off during smelting.

paper.dispose: Keep paper clean and dry, stack or bundle it, and place it in your paper recycling bin. Remove contaminants such as plastic windows where required.
reduce: Opt into digital billing, ticketing, and note-taking platforms.
Print only when necessary and default to double-sided settings.
Use cloth napkins, towels, and handkerchiefs in place of disposables.
Borrow or share books and magazines via libraries or community shelves.
Choose products with minimal packaging or certified recycled content.
reuse: Shred sensitive documents for compost carbon or pet bedding.
Fold scrap paper into memo pads or grocery lists.
Use newspaper as protective wrap when moving or shipping fragile items.
Create papier-mâché art, masks, or plantable seed paper.
Line pet cages or litter boxes with layered newsprint.
recycle_ideas: Blend shredded paper with flour glue to mold decorative bowls.
Press handmade paper sheets embedded with seeds for gifts.
Create origami garlands or seasonal decorations.
Layer paper bricks with clay for lightweight insulating blocks.
Weave magazine strips into baskets or coasters.
paper.environmental_impact: Paper production drives deforestation, consumes water, and requires bleaching chemicals. Recycling paper reduces tree harvesting and cuts landfill methane emissions.
paper.local_rules: Accepted grades typically include newspapers, office paper, and magazines. Keep pizza boxes or food-soiled paper out of recycling streams unless your city composts them.

cardboard.dispose: Flatten boxes, remove tape or plastic inserts when practical, and keep them dry before placing in recycling or reuse programs.
reduce: Consolidate online orders to fewer shipments or choose in-store pickup.
Support retailers that offer reusable delivery totes or returnable crates.
Decline oversized boxes for small items when offered alternate packaging.
Store seasonal decor or clothing in durable bins instead of new boxes.
Coordinate neighborhood sharing of moving boxes to extend their life.
reuse: Layer cardboard as a weed-suppressing sheet mulch in gardens.
Cut pieces into drawer dividers or closet organizers.
Create costume armor or play structures for children.
Use thick panels as protective surfaces for art and DIY projects.
Build cat scratchers or pet forts from stacked corrugated sheets.
recycle_ideas: Paint and hinge panels into lightweight photo backdrops.
Carve relief art or signage using laser cutters or craft knives.
Laminate layers with eco-friendly glue to build small furniture prototypes.
Cut hexagons to assemble geodesic domes for classroom demonstrations.
Shred and mix with compost to add carbon-rich bulking material.
cardboard.environmental_impact: Cardboard manufacturing requires pulp, water, and energy; recycling significantly reduces virgin fiber demand and keeps bulky material out of landfills.
cardboard.local_rules: Most curbside programs take corrugated cardboard and paperboard. Avoid waxed or heavily soiled boxes unless your municipality composts them. Tie bundles if requested.

organic waste.dispose: Collect food scraps, coffee grounds, and yard clippings for backyard composting or municipal organics bins. Keep animal protein separate if your program disallows it.
reduce: Plan meals and shopping lists to match actual consumption patterns.
Store produce properly using breathable bags and moisture control.
Batch-cook and freeze leftovers to extend shelf life.
Embrace root-to-stem cooking by using greens, peels, and stems.
Donate unopened pantry items before they expire.
reuse: Simmer vegetable trimmings into stock before composting.
Dry citrus peels for natural cleaners or potpourri.
Regrow scallions, lettuce, or celery from kitchen scraps.
Feed suitable scraps to backyard chickens or worm bins.
Use coffee grounds as gentle exfoliants or garden pest deterrents.
recycle_ideas: Create bokashi buckets for fermenting food waste in small spaces.
Build worm composting towers for apartment balconies.
Layer lasagna gardens with alternating greens and browns.
Produce bioenzymes by fermenting fruit peels with sugar.
Craft seedling starter pots from compressed compost and shredded paper.
organic waste.environmental_impact: When organic matter decomposes anaerobically in landfills, it generates methane, a potent greenhouse gas. Composting returns nutrients to soil, improves water retention, and stores carbon.
organic waste.local_rules: Many cities provide green bins for food and yard waste. Exclude plastics, glass, and synthetic liners. In regions without municipal service, establish backyard composters that comply with local wildlife ordinances.

e-waste.dispose: Never place electronics in household trash. Deliver devices to certified e-waste recyclers or manufacturer take-back events where hazardous components are safely handled.
reduce: Extend device lifespan with repairs, OS updates, and component upgrades.
Choose modular, repairable gadgets vetted by right-to-repair scores.
Share seldom-used electronics through tool libraries or rental platforms.
Adopt cloud or thin-client solutions to reduce redundant hardware.
Purchase refurbished equipment with warranty support.
reuse: Donate working laptops or tablets to schools, shelters, or mutual-aid groups.
Convert old smartphones into security cameras or baby monitors.
Use outdated tablets as smart home dashboards or recipe stations.
Harvest components like fans, LEDs, or speakers for maker projects.
Turn circuit boards into art pieces, jewelry, or educational displays.
recycle_ideas: Disassemble keyboards for keycap mosaics or typography art.
Use copper wire from power cords in sculptural projects.
Embed hard-drive platters in mirrors or kinetic mobiles.
Upcycle motherboard fragments into coasters with epoxy resin.
Repurpose sturdy casings as enclosures for DIY electronics.
e-waste.environmental_impact: Electronics contain toxic metals, flame retardants, and precious resources. Improper disposal contaminates soil and water, while responsible recycling recovers valuable copper, gold, and rare earth elements.
e-waste.local_rules: Many jurisdictions mandate e-waste recycling. Locate certified R2 or e-Stewards facilities, wipe data before drop-off, and follow manufacturer mail-back instructions when offered.
